oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Quantitative analysis of probabilistic models of software product lines with statistical model checking
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ter Beek, Maurice H.
Legay, Axel
Lluch Lafuente, Alberto
Vandin, Andrea
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Software Product Lines
Probabilistic Models
Quantitative Analysis
Statistical Model Checking
Process Algebra
Maude
MultiVeStA
info:eu-repo/classification/acm/D.2.4 Software/Program Verification. Formal Methods
info:eu-repo/classification/acm/D.2.4 Software/Program Verification. Model checking
info:eu-repo/classification/acm/F.3.1 Specifying and Verifying and Reasoning about Programs
info:eu-repo/classification/acm/F.3.2 Semantics of Programming Languages
info:eu-repo/classification/acm/G.3 Probability and Statistics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We investigate the suitability of statistical model checking techniques for analysing quantitative properties of software product line models with probabilistic aspects. For this purpose, we enrich the feature-oriented language FLan with action rates, which specify the likelihood of exhibiting particular behaviour or of installing features at a specific moment or in a specific order. The enriched language (called PFLan) allows us to specify models of software product lines with probabilistic configurations and behaviour, e.g. by considering a PFLan semantics based on discrete-time Markov chains. The Maude implementation of PFLan is combined with the distributed statistical model checker MultiVeStA to perform quantitative analyses of a simple product line case study. The presented analyses include the likelihood of certain behaviour of interest (e.g. product malfunctioning) and the expected average cost of products.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: info:eu-repo/grantAgreement/EC/FP7/600708/EU/A Quantitative Approach to Management and Design of Collective and Adaptive Behaviours/QUANTICOL
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: In: FMSPLE'15 - 6th International Workshop on Formal Methods for Software Product Line Engineering (London, UK, 11 April 2015). Proceedings, pp. 56 - 70. J.M. Atlee, S. Gnesi (eds.). (Electronic Proceedings in Theoretical Computer Science, vol. 182). EPTC
